statement.tex: \\ %text Given an integral \[I = \int\frac{ax+b}{\sqrt{cx^2+dx+e}}\cdot dx\] which of the following ways of \underline\text{re-writing} the integral \underline\text{will make it easier to evaluate}? %

\\ %text \underline\text{What are the values of 'p' and 'q'} given that % \begin{align} I &= \int\frac{6x+7}{\sqrt{(x-4)\cdot(x-5)}}\cdot dx \\ &= \int\frac{p\cdot\lbrace\frac{d}{dx}(x-4)\cdot(x-5)\rbrace + q}{\sqrt{(x-4)\cdot(x-5)}}\cdot dx \end{align}
\\ %text In $I= I_1 + I_2$, \underline\text{what will $I_1$ evaluate to}? \[\underbrace{3\int\frac{2x-9}{\sqrt{x^2-9x+20}}\cdot dx}_{I_1} + \underbrace{34\int\frac{dx}{\sqrt{x^2-9x+20}}}_{I_2}\] %

reason.tex:
%text The idea is to express the integral \[ I = \int\frac{ax+b}{\sqrt{cx^2+dx+e}}\cdot dx \] \underline\text{in terms of} integrals that we \underline\text{already know}.
And in this case, it is best to do the following
%
\begin{align} I &= p\cdot I_1 + q\cdot I_2 \text{ where } \\ I_1 &=\underbrace{ \int\frac{\frac{d}{dx}f(x)}{\sqrt{f(x)}}\cdot dx =\int\frac{d\phi}{\sqrt{\phi}}}_{\phi=f(x)\implies f'(x)dx=d\phi}\\ I_2 &= \int\frac{dx}{\sqrt{(x+m)^2 + n^2}} \end{align}

\begin{align} (x-4)\cdot (x-5) &= x^2-9x + 20 \\ \implies\frac{d}{dx}(x-4)\cdot(x-5) &= 2x-9 \end{align}\\ \begin{align} \therefore I &= \int\frac{6x+7}{\sqrt{(x-4)\cdot(x-5)}}\cdot dx \\ &= \int\frac{p\cdot (2x-9) + q}{\sqrt{x^2-9x+20}}\cdot dx \\ &=\int\frac{2px + (q-9p)}{\sqrt{x^2-9x+20}}\cdot dx \\ \implies 2p&= 6\text{ and } q-9p = 7 \\ \text{or }p &= 3\text{ and }q = 7 + 9\cdot 3 = 34 \end{align}

%text To evaluate integrals of the form \[\qquad \int\frac{dx}{\sqrt{cx^2+dx+e}} \]
the best strategy is to \underline\text{complete the squares} - as shown below. % \begin{align} x^2-9x+20 &= \left(x-\frac{9}{2} \right)^2 -\left(\frac{9}{2}\right)^2 + 20 \\ &= \left(x-\frac{9}{2}\right)^2 -\frac{1}{4}\\ &= \left(x-\frac{9}{2}\right)^2 -\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^2 \end{align}\\ \begin{align} \therefore I_2 &= 34\int\frac{dx}{\sqrt{x^2-9x+20}} \\ &= 34\underbrace{\int\frac{dx}{\sqrt{\left(x-\frac{9}{2}\right)^2 -\frac{1}{2^2}}}} _{\int\frac{dx}{\sqrt{x^2-a^2}}= \log\vert x + \sqrt{x^2-a^2}\vert} \\ &= 34\cdot\log\left\vert \left( x-\frac{9}{2}\right) + \sqrt{x^2-9x+20} \right\vert \end{align}
